724019f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
724019f-a.text:
Washington Square Park: The Washington Arch and Fifth Avenue northward, photographed from a point in the park. At the left is the Rhinelander home.
About 1895
Gift of Urbrock Collection

708295f.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square
708295f.text:
Washington Square, looking up Fifth Avenue and showing the Washington Memorial Arch.
1900's

724021f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724021f-a.text:
Washington Arch, Washington Square North, at Fifth Avenue, a night view looking north from the park.

The Washington Arch, built in 1890 to commemorate the inauguration of President Washington in New York, is shown illuminated by electric lights at the time of the Hudson-Fulton Centenary celebration.

1909.
August Loeffler, from P. L. Sperr Collection.
724021f-a.folder: Washington Square North & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

731257f-b.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - National Guard and Naval Reserve Units.
731257f-b.text:
Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: Three views of National Guard and Naval Reserve units marching northward on Fifth Avenue from Washington Square. These contingents have just passed W. 10th Street (in views 1 and 2), at the N. W. corner of which appears a portion of the Church of the Ascension. View 3 is photographed in the opposite direction. At the left is the lst Presbyterian Church occupying the avenue frontage from 11th to 12th Streets. Note the new 8 story Mac Millan and Co. Building under construction at the N. W. corner of 12th Street.
1924
MAY BE REPRODUCED  Views 1,2,3
731257f-b.folder: 5th Avenue and Washington Square, Manhattan, N.Y.

724018f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
724018f-a.text:
Washington Square (Park): The Washington Memorial Arch viewing northward and up Fifth Avenue. Buildings on the left and right of same, are respectively the Rhinelander and Sailor's Snug Harbor holdings, fronting on the north side of Washington Square North. Note that at this date the huge apartment house (No 1 Fifth Avenue) has not been erected and that the old Hotel Brevoort stll stands.
June 1925

MAY BE REPRODUCED  Neg. #584

708294f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square
708294f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from and including Washington Square North and Washington Arch. The Empire State Building, in the background, is not quite completed.
Autumn 1930.
William Frange.
Gift of Bernhard Hoffmann.

724007f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724007f-a.text:
19, 18, 17, 16-14 Washington Square North at N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue, the old Rhinelander houses. The large house at the corner was made by rebuilding old 14, 1S, and 16. Compare
Brown Brothers' view of this block in 1905.
November 19, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
724007f-a.folder: Washington Square North & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

724010f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724010f-a.text:
18-24 Washington Square North, between Fifth Avenue and MacDougal Street.
Novenber 19, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

724020f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
724020f-a.text:
Vashincton Scuare Park:
Washington Arch, Washington Square, seen from the north so as to show the Judson Memorial Baptist Church (1892) framed in the archway, and the fountain in the center of the park. The church stands on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street and Washington Scuare
South (4th Street).
This arch was built around 1890; the wooden one designed by Stanford White for the Centenary of President Washington's inauguration, in 1889, was so well liked that it was decided to erect a permanent
arch of stone, which White also designed.
May S, 1233.
P. L. Sperr.

723991f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square East - 5th Avenue
723991f-a.text:
Washington Square Park, the eastern side, seen from the S.E. corner,
with One Fifth Avenue in the background.
May 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
723991f-a.folder: Washington Square East & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

724008f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724008f-b.text:
Washington Square North, at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue, as viewed from several different angles and showing at that location the "Rhinelander" an apartment house that was formerly the residence of the family of that name. View No. 1 is northward from in back of the Washington Arch while Nos. 2 and 3 are westward from and across
the Avenue.
May 7, 1938
View 2: May 1, 1937
View 31 Aug. 25, 1933
P. L. Sperr,
724008f-b.folder: Washington Square North & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

708293f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square
708293f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north from Washington Square, seen through Washington Arch. The day on which this exposure was made was gratifyingly clear. The Empire State Building, the tallest building in the world, at 34th Street, stands out well, and even 500 Fifth Avenue, at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, can be plainly
discerned.
July 17, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

723992f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 5th Avenue
723992f-b.text:
Washington Square Park, eastern half, seen across the Square from
a building near the S.W. corner.
This view is almost straight east on Washington Square South (4th Street), showing the Judson Memorial Church (1892) and the clearing made about 1927 on the S.E. corner of Thompson
Street.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but a little further to the north, showing part of the new One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel (1926), and not
showing Washington Square South.
The apartment building on the N.E. corner of University and Waverly Places was erected in 1929. Compare both these views
with Ewing Galloway's picture taken about 1924.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
723992f-b.folder: Washington Square South & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

723992f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 5th Avenue
723992f-a.text:

a building near the S.W. corner.

723979f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - [5th Avenue.]
723979f-a.text:
Washington Square with statue of Garibaldi, Manhattan
Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer
Neg. No. 191
[Note: negative at Museum of the City ofNew York]
Code I B
Dec. 29, 1936

708304f-b.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square North
708304f-b.text:
Fifth Aveue, west side, between Washington Square North and West 8th Street, showing the 2 story residence of Chancellor Chase of N.Y.U. This is to the rear of the rebuilt Rhinelander apartment building at the N.W. corner of W.S. North and the Avenue. To the right are three 4 story residences bearing No's 4, 6 & 8 Fifth Avenue. The last enumerated is at the S.W. corner of 8th Street. View 2 shows this last mentioned thoroughfare, including both corners. No. 3 is southward to the park. Forming a background here is the aforementioned Rhinelander building.
View 1: March 1, 1931 Neg #521
View 2, 3: June 11, 1933 Neg #522, 523
F.L.Sperr
708304f-b.folder: 5th Avenue & Washington Square North, Manhattan, NY

723982f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
723982f-a.text:
Washirgton Square (Park)1 A set of 3 views of the Washington Arch, located on the northerly side at Fifth Avenue as viewed from several different angles. Beyond same apnears the large apartment house, No. 1 Fifth Avenue which was erected around 1927. The low structures bordering this side, face on a thoroughfare known as
Washington Square North.
Autumn 1930
Gift of Bernhard Hoffman
William Frange
P. L. Sperr,  View 2Dec. 28, 1927
NO RRPRODUCTIONS.  View 31May 7, 1938.

723997f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
723997f-a.text: 14-22 Washington Square North, looking west from Fifth Avenue. These fine old residences antedate the Civil War. In front of No. 15 is the spot where Sandy Hill Road, a part of which has become Greenwich Avenue and another part of which has become Aster Place, crossed the main branch of Minetta creek in the 18th Century. It is possible that this was the crossing at which the old "Kissing Bridge" was located. February 24,1922. Gift of E.M. Jenks.
723997f-a.folder: Washington Square North & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

724012f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724012f-b.text:
14-28 Washington Square North, from Fifth Avenue to Macdougal Street. These are almost all old residences of the pre-Civil War period, except the 7-story Richmond Hill on the N.E. corner of Macdougal Street, an apartment house built
about 1900.
1905.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
The same, twenty-three years later. The first three houses,
14-15-16, have been rebuilt as one unit.
October 4, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
724012f-b.folder: Washington Square North & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY
